trans-unit.source: Files declared as ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL will consist of records terminated by an end-of-record delimiter character or character sequence.

Files declared as ORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL will consist of records with no explicit end-of-record delimiter character sequences; records in such files are “delineated” by a calculated byte-offset (based on the maximum record length) into the file.

Files destined for use as sort/merge work files must be described with a Sort/Merge File Description (SD) while every other file is described with a File Description (FD). Each of these descriptions will almost always be followed with at least one record description.

Files destined for use as sort/merge work files must be described with a Sort/Merge File Description SD while every other file is described with a File Description FD. Each of these descriptions will almost always be followed with at least one record description.

Cada una de estas descripciones casi siempre irá seguida de al menos una descripción de registro.

trans-unit.source: Floating-point values using "Enn" notation such as 9.92E25, representing 9.92 x 10^25 (10 raised to the 25th power) or 5.7E-14, representing 5.7 x 10^-14 (10 raised to the -14th power). Both the mantissa (the number before the E) and the exponent (the number after the E) may be explicitly specified as positive (with a +), negative (with a -) or unsigned (and therefore implicitly positive). A floating-point literals value must be within the range -1.7 x 10^308 to +1.7 x 10^308 with no more than 15 decimal digits of precision.
trans-unit.target: Valores en coma flotante usando la notación "Enn" como 9,92E25,que representa 9,92 x 10^25 (10 elevado a la 25ª potencia)o 5,7E-14,que representa 5,7 x 10^-14 (10 elevado a la -14ª potencia).Tanto la mantisa (el número anterior a la E)como el exponente (el número posterior a la E)pueden especificarse explícitamente como positivos (con un +),negativos (con un -)o sin signo (y por lo tanto implícitamente positivos).Un valor literal en coma flotante debe estar dentro del rango de -1,7 x 10^308 a +1,7 x 10^308 con no más de 15 dígitos decimales de precisión.

trans-unit.source: For example, on a GnuCOBOL build for a Windows PC using MinGW and “PDCurses”, F1–F12 are the actual F-keys on the PC keyboard, F13–F24 are entered by shifting the F-keys, F25–F36 are entered by holding Ctrl while pressing an F-key and F37–F48 are entered by holding Alt while pressing an F-key. On the other hand, a GnuCOBOL implementation built for Windows using Cygwin and NCurses treats the PCs F1–F12 keys as the actual F1–F12, while shifted F-keys will enter F11–F20. With Cygwin/NCurses, Ctrl- and Alt-modified F-keys aren’t recognized, nor are Shift-F11 or Shift-F12.

For quite a while now (back to the late 1970’s), the

For quite a while now (back to the late 1970’s), the "sequence number area" of a COBOL statement (columns 1-6) has come to be used as a change indicator area. Programmers would place a code in columns 1-6 of every line they changed in a program. The author works in a COBOL shop where change indicators of the form "xxmmyy" are required on every altered line of a program — "xx" is the initials of the programmer while "mmyy" are the month and two-digit year of the date the change was made. This is frequently accompanied by a comment block at or near the top of a COBOL program providing general documentation of what changes were made and what change indicator was used to mark that change.
trans-unit.target: Desde hace bastante tiempo (desde finales de la década de 1970), el "área de número de secuencia" de una declaración COBOL (columnas 1-6) se ha venido utilizando como un área de indicador de cambio. Los programadores colocarían un código en las columnas 1-6 de cada línea que cambiaran en un programa. El autor trabaja en una tienda COBOL donde se requieren indicadores de cambio de la forma "xxmmyy" en cada línea modificada de un programa: "xx" son las iniciales del programador mientras que "mmyy" son el mes y el año de dos dígitos de la fecha. se hizo el cambio. Esto suele ir acompañado de un bloque de comentarios en o cerca de la parte superior de un programa COBOL que proporciona documentación general de qué cambios se realizaron y qué indicador de cambio se utilizó para marcar ese cambio.

trans-unit.source: GnuCOBOL controls concurrent-file access at the highest level through the concept of file sharing, enforced when a program attempts to open a file. This is accomplished via a UNIX operating-system routine called fcntl. That module is not currently supported by Windows and is not present in the MinGW Unix-emulation package. GnuCOBOL builds created using a MinGW environment will be incapable of supporting file-sharing controls — files will always be shared in such environments. A GnuCOBOL build created using the Cygwin environment on Windows

trans-unit.source: GnuCOBOL fully supports much of the ANSI 85 standard for COBOL (the only major exclusion is the Communications Module) and also supports some of the components of the COBOL2002 and COBOL2014 standards, such as the SCREEN SECTION (see SCREEN SECTION), table-based SORT (see Table SORT) and user-defined functions. There are others with more being added almost weekly.

GnuCOBOL fully supports much of the ANSI 85 standard for COBOL (the only major exclusion is the Communications Module) and also supports some of the components of the COBOL2002 standard, such as theSCREEN SECTION(see SCREEN SECTION), table-basedSORT(see Table SORT) and user-defined functions.
trans-unit.target: GnuCOBOL es totalmente compatible con gran parte del estándar ANSI 85 para COBOL (la única exclusión importante es el módulo de comunicaciones) y también admite algunos de los componentes del estándar COBOL2002, como la SCREEN SECTION (consulte la SECCIÓN DE PANTALLA ), SORT basado en tablas (consulte Table SORT ) y funciones definidas por el usuario.

GnuCOBOL includes an implementation of the Report Writer Control System, or RWCS. The reportwriter module is now fully implemented as of version 3.0. This is a standardized, optional add-on feature to the COBOL language which automates much of the mechanics involved in the generation of printed reports by:

GnuCOBOL is a free and open sourced COBOL compiler and runtime environment, written using the C programming language. GnuCOBOL is typically distributed in source-code form, and must then be built for your computer’s operating system using the system’s C compiler and loader. While originally developed for the UNIX and Linux operating systems, GnuCOBOL has also been successfully built for computers running OSX and Windows utilizing the UNIX-emulation features of such tools as Cygwin and MinGW. Also see the GNU website for more information at.

trans-unit.source: GnuCOBOL provides for control over the final rounding process applied to the receiving fields on all arithmetic verbs. Each of the arithmetic statements (ADD (see ADD), COMPUTE (see COMPUTE), DIVIDE (see DIVIDE), MULTIPLY (see MULTIPLY) and SUBTRACT (see SUBTRACT)) statements allow an optional ROUNDED clause to be applied to each receiving data item.

GnuCOBOL run-time screen management must have been initialized prior to CALLing this routine in order to receive meaningful values. This means that a DISPLAY screen-data-item statement (see DISPLAY screen-data-item) or a ACCEPT screen-data-item statement (see ACCEPT screen-data-item) must have been executed prior to executing the CALL statement.

GnuCOBOL run-time screen management must have been initialized prior to CALLing this routine in order to receive meaningful values. This means that aDISPLAY screen-data-itemstatement (see DISPLAY screen-data-item) or aACCEPT screen-data-itemstatement (see ACCEPT screen-data-item) must have been executed prior to executing theCALLstatement.
trans-unit.target: La administración de la pantalla en tiempo de ejecución de GnuCOBOL debe haberse inicializado antes de llamar a esta rutina para recibir valores significativos. Esto significa que un DISPLAY screen-data-item declaración (véase visualización de la pantalla-data-item ) o un ACCEPT screen-data-item declaración (véase Accept-datos de pantalla del tema ) deben haber sido ejecutados con anterioridad a la ejecución de la CALL comunicado.

trans-unit.source: Here’s a more practical view of the difference. Let’s say that a table has 1,000 entries in it. With a sequential search, on average, you’ll have to check 500 of them to find an entry and you’ll have to look at all 1,000 of them to find that an entry doesn’t exist.
trans-unit.target: Aquí hay una vista más práctica de la diferencia. Digamos que una tabla tiene 1,000 entradas. Con una búsqueda secuencial, en promedio, tendrá que verificar 500 de ellos para encontrar una entrada y tendrá que mirar los 1,000 para encontrar que una entrada no existe.

trans-unit.source: Historically in the early 60’s programs were first punched on to paper tape and by the mid 60’s that was replaced almost totally, by punched cards although paper tape was still used by programmers for the odd few changes to their sources held on magnetic tape or disk as a portable paper tape punch could be put in your pocket. Now the problem with punched cards were there was 2,000 cards per box and that they could and did, get dropped. So, cc (column) 1 through 6 had the card sequence number in and that way if a box was dropped they could be feed in to a card sorter to be fixed. This was after the cards was cleaned up so that they were all in the same direction which one corner cut out helped.
trans-unit.target: Históricamente, a principios de los años 60, los programas se perforaron por primera vez en cinta de papel y, a mediados de los 60, fue reemplazada casi en su totalidad por tarjetas perforadas, aunque los programadores todavía usaban cinta de papel para los pocos cambios en sus fuentes que se mantenían en cinta magnética o disco como un perforador de cinta de papel portátil se puede poner en su bolsillo. Ahora, el problema con las tarjetas perforadas era que había 2.000 tarjetas por caja y que podían caer y se cayeron. Entonces, cc (columna) 1 a 6 tenía el número de secuencia de la tarjeta y, de esa manera, si se dejaba caer una caja, podían introducirse en un clasificador de tarjetas para que se reparara. Esto fue después de que se limpiaron las tarjetas para que estuvieran todas en la misma dirección, lo que ayudó a recortar una esquina.

trans-unit.source: Historically, back in the days when punched-cards were used to submit COBOL program source to a COBOL compiler, this part of a COBOL statement was reserved for a six-digit sequence number. While the contents of this area are ignored by COBOL compilers, it existed so that a program actually punched on 80-character cards could — if the card deck were dropped on the floor — be run through a card sorter machine and restored to it’s proper sequence. Of course, this isn’t necessary today; if truth be told, it hasn’t been necessary for a long time.
trans-unit.target: Históricamente, en los días en que se usaban tarjetas perforadas para enviar la fuente del programa COBOL a un compilador COBOL, esta parte de una declaración COBOL estaba reservada para un número de secuencia de seis dígitos. Si bien los compiladores de COBOL ignoran el contenido de esta área, existía de modo que un programa realmente perforado en tarjetas de 80 caracteres podría, si la baraja de cartas se cayera al suelo, ejecutarse a través de una máquina clasificadora de tarjetas y restaurarse a su secuencia correcta . Por supuesto, esto no es necesario hoy; a decir verdad, no ha sido necesario durante mucho tiempo.

trans-unit.source: Historically, back in the days when punched-cards were used to submit COBOL program source to a COBOL compiler, this part of a COBOL statement was reserved for a six-digit sequence number. While the contents of this area are ignored by COBOL compilers, it existed so that a program actually punched on 80-character cards could — if the card deck were dropped on the floor — be run through a card sorter machine and restored to its proper sequence. Of course, this isn’t necessary today; if truth be told, it hasn’t been necessary for a long time.

trans-unit.source: I do not use THRU on any MERGE, PERFORM or SORT statement unless the programming standards of the shop in which I am working require it. My reasoning for this is that it is too easy to accidentally introduce a new procedure into the scope of a THRU.

trans-unit.source: Identified sub strings will be moved into each destination field in the sequence they are identified; values moved into a destination field will be truncated if the sub string length exceeds the destination field length, or padded with spaces if the destination field length exceeds the sub string length. Both truncation and padding will be controlled by the presence or absence of a JUSTIFIED (see JUSTIFIED) clause on the destination field.

Identified sub strings will be moved into each destination field in the sequence they are identified; values moved into a destination field will be truncated if the sub string length exceeds the destination field length, or padded with spaces if the destination field length exceeds the sub string length. Both truncation and padding will be controlled by the presence or absence of aJUSTIFIED(see JUSTIFIED) clause on the destination field.
trans-unit.target: Las subcadenas identificadas se moverán a cada campo de destino en la secuencia en que se identifican; los valores movidos a un campo de destino se truncarán si la longitud de la subcadena excede la longitud del campo de destino, o se rellenarán con espacios si la longitud del campo de destino excede la longitud de la subcadena. Tanto el truncamiento como el relleno serán controlados por la presencia o ausencia de una cláusula JUSTIFIED (ver JUSTIFIED ) en el campo de destino.

If <var>argument-1</var> is a combined date and time format, the content of <var>argument-2</var> shall be a valid combined date and time in same format.
If <var>argument-1</var> is a date format the content of <var>argument-2</var> shall be a valid date in that format.

If <var>argument-2</var> is specified, each character in <var>argument-1</var> that has no corresponding national representation is converted to the substitution character specified by <var>argument-2</var>.

If <var>argument-2</var> is specified, the alphanumeric substitution character is returned for each national character in <var>argument-1</var> that has no corresponding alphanumeric character representation.

If <var>argument-2</var> is un-specified, and <var>argument-1</var> contains a national character for which there is no corresponding alphanumeric character representation, an substitution character is used as the corresponding alphanumeric character and the EC-DATA-CONVERSION exception condition is set.

If argument-2 is unspecified and argument-1 contains an alphanumeric character for which there is no corresponding national character representation, a substitution character is used as the corresponding national character and the EC-DATA-CONVERSION exception condition is set to exist.
If <var>argument-4</var> is unspecified, the highest level defined in the ordering table is used for the comparison.

If conditional-expression evaluates to TRUE, imperative-statement-1 will be executed regardless of whether or not an ELSE clause is present. Once imperative-statement-1 has been executed, control falls into the first statement following the END-IF or to the first statement of the next sentence if there is no END-IF clause.
If <var>convert-length</var> is negative or zero, no conversion will be performed.

If file-name-1 is a relative file, identifier-1 must be the defined RELATIVE KEY of the file.

If identifier-1 is a BASED data item and that data item is currently based (meaning it currently has memory allocated to it), its memory is released and identifier-1 will become un-based and therefore unusable. If identifier-1 was not based, no action will be taken.

If identifier-1 is a USAGE POINTER data item and it contains a valid address, the FREE statement will release the memory block the pointer references. In addition, any BASED data items that the pointer was used to provide an address for will become un-based and therefore unusable. If identifier-1 did not contain a valid address, no action will be taken.

If identifier-1 is a numeric data item, the character value read from the console or standard-input device will be parsed according to the rules for input to the NUMVAL intrinsic function (see NUMVAL), except that none of the trailing sign formats are honoured.
If <var>identifier-1</var> is coded, the value of the identifier will serve as the File Location String that will identify the data file.

If identifier-1 is defined as numeric edited, entered data must be acceptable as NUMVAL-C intrinsic function (see NUMVAL-C) input (again, no decimal points are allowed). The value stored into identifier-1 will be as if the input were passed to that function.

If identifier-1 is defined as numeric, entered data must be acceptable as NUMVAL intrinsic function (see NUMVAL) input (no decimal points are allowed, however). The value stored into identifier-1 will be as if the input were passed to that function.

If identifier-1 is defined in the SCREEN SECTION (see SCREEN SECTION), any AT, Attribute-Specification and WITH clauses will be ignored. All field definition, cursor positioning and screen control will occur as a result of the screen section definition of identifier-1.

If identifier-1 is defined in the SCREEN SECTION (see SCREEN SECTION), any AT, Attribute-Specification, LOWER, UPPER or SCROLL clauses will be ignored. In these cases, an implied DISPLAY (see DISPLAY screen-data-item) of identifier-1 will occur before input is accepted. Coding an explicit DISPLAY identifier-1 before an ACCEPT identifier-1 is redundant and will incur the performance penalty of painting the screen contents twice.

If identifier-1 is used to specify either an absolute or relative column position, identifier-1 must be defined as a numeric item of any USAGE (see USAGE) other than COMPUTATIONAL-1 or COMPUTATIONAL-2, without editing symbols. The value of identifier-1 at the time the screen data item is presented must be 1 or greater. Note that a COMPUTATIONAL-1 or COMPUTATIONAL-2 identifier will be accepted by the compiler, but will produce unpredictable results at run-time.

If identifier-1 or any screen data item subordinate to it are defined as numeric edited, entered data must be acceptable as NUMVAL-C intrinsic function (see NUMVAL-C) input (again, no decimal points are allowed). The value stored into the screen data item will be as if the input were passed to that function.

If identifier-1 or any screen data item subordinate to it are defined as numeric, entered data must be acceptable as NUMVAL intrinsic function (see NUMVAL) input (no decimal points are allowed, however). The value stored into the screen data item will be as if the input were passed to that function.

If literal-1 is specified, only the TALLYING clause may be specified.

trans-unit.source: If COB_SET_TRACE is set to Y, then tracing will always occur regardless of the presence of READY TRACE or RESET TRACE so in effect they will have no action on program execution.

trans-unit.source: If Replace Mode is currently active, a REPLACE LAST OFF. will replace the current replace specification(s) with those popped off the top of the stack. If there were no replace specification(s) on the stack, the effect will be as if a REPLACE OFF. had been coded.

If Replace Mode is currently active, a REPLACE OFF. will deactivate Replace Mode and discard any replace specification(s) on the stack. The compiler will henceforth operate as if no REPLACE had ever been encountered, until such time as another Format 1 REPLACE is encountered.

trans-unit.source: If an argument lacks a BY clause, the most-recently encountered BY specification on that CALL statement will be assumed. If the first argument specified on a CALL lacks a BY clause, BY REFERENCE will be assumed.

If it is a dynamic subroutine, the GnuCOBOL run-time system will check to see if a dynamically-loadable module containing the subprogram’s entry point was already located. If it was, no further "location" activity is needed. If not, the dynamically-loadable module will be located (see Locating Dynamically-Loadable Modules).
trans-unit.target: Si es una subrutina dinámica, el sistema de tiempo de ejecución de GnuCOBOL verificará si ya se localizó un módulo cargable dinámicamente que contenga el punto de entrada del subprograma. Si fue así, no se necesita más actividad de "ubicación". De lo contrario, se ubicará el módulo cargable dinámicamente (consulte Ubicación de módulos cargables dinámicamente ).

trans-unit.source: If it is a dynamic subroutine, the GnuCOBOL run-time system will check to see if a dynamically-loadable module containing the subprogram’s entry point was already located. If it was, no further “location” activity is needed. If not, the dynamically-loadable module will be located (see Locating Dynamically-Loadable Modules).

If it is a dynamic user-defined function, the GnuCOBOL run-time system will check to see if a dynamically-loadable module containing the function’s entry point was already located. If it was, no further "location" activity is needed. If not, the dynamically-loadable module will be located (see Locating Dynamically-Loadable Modules).
trans-unit.target: Si se trata de una función dinámica definida por el usuario, el sistema de tiempo de ejecución de GnuCOBOL comprobará si ya se encuentra un módulo cargable dinámicamente que contenga el punto de entrada de la función. Si fue así, no se necesita más actividad de "ubicación". De lo contrario, se ubicará el módulo cargable dinámicamente (consulte Ubicación de módulos cargables dinámicamente ).

trans-unit.source: If it is a dynamic user-defined function, the GnuCOBOL run-time system will check to see if a dynamically-loadable module containing the function’s entry point was already located. If it was, no further “location” activity is needed. If not, the dynamically-loadable module will be located (see Locating Dynamically-Loadable Modules).
If it is a static subroutine, it will already be part of the executable program issuing the CALL (see CALL).
If it is a static subroutine, it will already be part of the executable program issuing theCALL(see CALL).
trans-unit.target: Si es una subrutina estática, ya será parte del programa ejecutable que emite la CALL (ver CALL ).

trans-unit.source: If it is a static user-defined function, it will already be part of the executable file containing the calling program.
trans-unit.target: Si se trata de una función estática definida por el usuario,ya formará parte del archivo ejecutable que contiene el programa de llamada.

If no COLLATING SEQUENCE clause is specified, the collating sequence implied by the character set native to the computer (usually ASCII) will be used.

trans-unit.source: If references to table elements are going to be performed many, many times (tens or hundreds of thousands of times or more) during program execution, you will probably see a noticeable reduction in program execution time if you use indexing versus subscripting.
trans-unit.target: Si las referencias a los elementos de la tabla se van a realizar muchas,muchas veces (decenas o cientos de miles de veces o más)durante la ejecución del programa,probablemente verá una notable reducción del tiempo de ejecución del programa si utiliza la indexación frente a la subscripción.

trans-unit.source: If references to table elements are not going to be performed many, many times it probably won’t make much difference whether you use indexing or subscripting.
trans-unit.target: Si las referencias a los elementos de la tabla no se van a realizar muchas, muchas veces probablemente no hará mucha diferencia si usa indexación o subíndice.

trans-unit.source: If rule

If rule (A) is violated, the compiler will reject theSEARCH ALL If rules (B) and/or (C) are violated, there will be no message issued by the compiler, but the run-time results of aSEARCH ALLagainst the table will probably be incorrect.
trans-unit.target: Si se viola la regla (A), el compilador rechazará la SEARCH ALL Si se violan las reglas (B) y / o (C), no habrá ningún mensaje emitido por el compilador, pero los resultados en tiempo de ejecución de una SEARCH ALL contra la tabla probablemente sea incorrecta.

trans-unit.source: If set to "Y", "y" or "1", aCANCELstatement (see CANCEL) will physically unload a subprogram dynamically-loadable module.
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en "Y", "y" o "1", una instrucción CANCEL (ver CANCEL ) descargará físicamente un subprograma de módulo cargable dinámicamente.

trans-unit.source: If set to ‘

If set to a value of "Y", any run-time warnings (such as noting the implicit closing of open files when aGOBACKstatement (see GOBACK) orSTOPstatement (see STOP) with theRUNoption is executed) will be displayed. Any other value for this environment variable (including not setting the variable at all) will suppress such messages.
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en un valor de "Y", se mostrarán todas las advertencias en tiempo de ejecución (como señalar el cierre implícito de archivos abiertos cuando se GOBACK una instrucción GOBACK (ver GOBACK ) o una instrucción STOP (ver STOP ) con la opción RUN ) . Cualquier otro valor para esta variable de entorno (incluida la no configuración de la variable) suprimirá dichos mensajes.

trans-unit.source: If set to a value of ‘

If set to a value of upper- or lower-case "p", this variable will force a file commit every time a file is written to (ensuring that data is immediately written to the file rather than retained in memory until a future commit occurs). This will slow-down update access to files, but will provide for better integrity in the event of a program failure.
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en un valor de "p" mayúscula o minúscula,esta variable forzará una confirmación de archivo cada vez que se escriba en un archivo (asegurando que los datos se escriban inmediatamente en el archivo en lugar de ser retenidos en la memoria hasta que se produzca una futura confirmación).Esto ralentizará el acceso de actualización a los archivos,pero proporcionará una mejor integridad en caso de que falle el programa.

trans-unit.source: If set to a value of upper- or lower-case ‘
If set to any non-blank value, this variable allows a ACCEPT screen-data-item statement (see ACCEPT screen-data-item) to detect the Esc key.
If set to any non-blank value, this variable allows aACCEPT screen-data-itemstatement (see ACCEPT screen-data-item) to detect the "Esc" key.
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en cualquier valor que no esté en blanco, esta variable permite una instrucción ACCEPT screen-data-item (ver ACCEPT screen-data-item ) para detectar la tecla "Esc".

trans-unit.source: If set to any non-null value, this environment variable specifies the file to which all
If set to any non-null value, this environment variable specifies the file to which all-ftraceswitch and-ftraceallswitch output will be written.
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en cualquier valor que no sea nulo, esta variable de entorno especifica el archivo en el que se -ftrace todas las salidas del conmutador -ftraceall y -ftraceall .

trans-unit.source: If set to any non-null value, this variable will cause all dynamically-loadable libraries to be loaded when the program begins execution (rather than searching for and loading the module upon first use).
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en cualquier valor no nulo,esta variable hará que todas las bibliotecas que se puedan cargar dinámicamente se carguen cuando el programa comience a ejecutarse (en lugar de buscar y cargar el módulo en el primer uso).

trans-unit.source: If set to anything else, aCANCELstatement (see CANCEL) logically unloads a module so that subsequent use will re-initialize the module as if it had actually been reloaded, but the overhead of actually reloading the module will be avoided.
trans-unit.target: Si se establece en cualquier otra cosa, una instrucción CANCEL (consulte CANCEL ) descarga lógicamente un módulo para que el uso posterior reinicialice el módulo como si realmente se hubiera recargado, pero se evitará la sobrecarga de recargar el módulo.

trans-unit.source: If set to either UPPER or LOWER, this environment variable will internally convert referenced entry-point names to either upper- or lower-case before initiating searches for dynamically-loadable modules. The UPPER and LOWER values of the environment variable are actually case-insensitive.

If set to eitherUPPERorLOWER this environment variable will internally convert referenced entry-point names to either upper- or lower-case before initiating searches for dynamically-loadable modules. TheUPPERandLOWERvalues of the environment variable are actually case-insensitive.

If the compiler "config" file (see Compiler Configuration Files) you used to compile the program specified "mf" as the "assign-clause" value, then the File Locator String will be interpreted according to Microfocus COBOL rules — namely, everything before the last "-" in the File Locator String will be ignored; the characters after the last "-" will be treated as the base of an environment variable name. If there is no "-" character in the File Locator String then the entire File Locator String will serve as the base of an environment variable name. This is the default behaviour for every config file except "ibm".
trans-unit.target: Si el archivo "config" del compilador (ver Archivos de configuración del compilador ) que usó para compilar el programa especificó "mf" como el valor de "asignar-cláusula", entonces la cadena del localizador de archivos se interpretará de acuerdo con las reglas COBOL de Microfocus, es decir, todo lo anterior se ignorará el último "-" en la cadena del localizador de archivos; los caracteres después del último "-" se tratarán como la base de un nombre de variable de entorno. Si no hay un carácter "-" en la cadena del localizador de archivos, toda la cadena del localizador de archivos servirá como base de un nombre de variable de entorno. Este es el comportamiento predeterminado para todos los archivos de configuración excepto "ibm".

Finalmente, si el valor del primer argumento es cualquier cosa menos cero, la rutina fallará con un valor 129.

trans-unit.source: If you like to hold a book in your hands, I strongly recommend

If you like to hold a book in your hands, I strongly recommend "Murach’s Structured COBOL", by Mike Murach, Anne Prince and Raul Menendez (2000) - ISBN 9781890774059. Mike Murach and his various writing partners have been writing outstanding COBOL textbooks for decades, and this text is no exception. It’s an excellent book for those familiar with the concepts of programming in other languages, but unfamiliar with COBOL.
trans-unit.target: Si te gusta tener un libro en tus manos, te recomiendo encarecidamente "Murach's Structured COBOL", de Mike Murach, Anne Prince y Raul Menendez (2000) - ISBN 9781890774059. Mike Murach y sus diversos compañeros de escritura han estado escribiendo excelentes libros de texto COBOL para décadas, y este texto no es una excepción. Es un libro excelente para aquellos que estén familiarizados con los conceptos de programación en otros lenguajes, pero que no estén familiarizados con COBOL.

trans-unit.source: If your GnuCOBOL build uses the Berkeley Database (BDB) package, use this environment variable to specify the folder in which the lock management files to be associated with all non-SORT files opened by the program will be stored. ORGANIZATION INDEXED (see ORGANIZATION INDEXED) files will also have their data file allocated in the folder pointed to by this environment variable, if it exists.. Having this variable defined will activate record locking features on the READ statement (see READ), REWRITE statement (see REWRITE) and WRITE statement (see WRITE). Even with DB_HOME, locking will not work with ORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL (see ORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL), ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL (see ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL) or ORGANIZATION RELATIVE files with GnuCOBOL builds created for Windows/MinGW. ORGANIZATION INDEXED locks will work with Windows/MinGW + BDB and all locks will work for all file organizations with UNIX GnuCOBOL builds.

Having this variable defined will activate record locking features on theREADstatement (see READ),REWRITEstatement (see REWRITE) andWRITEstatement (see WRITE). Even with DB_HOME, locking will not work withORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL(see ORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL),ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL(see ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL) or ORGANIZATION RELATIVE files with GnuCOBOL builds created for Windows/MinGW.ORGANIZATION INDEXEDlocks will work with Windows/MinGW + BDB and all locks will work for all file organizations with UNIX GnuCOBOL builds.
trans-unit.target: Si su compilación de GnuCOBOL usa el paquete Berkeley Database (BDB), use esta variable de entorno para especificar la carpeta en la que se almacenarán los archivos de administración de bloqueo que se asociarán con todos los archivos que no sean SORT abiertos por el programa. ORGANIZATION INDEXED (ver ORGANIZATION INDEXED ) también tendrán su archivo de datos asignado en la carpeta a la que apunta esta variable de entorno, si existe. Tener esta variable definida activará las funciones de bloqueo de registros en la instrucción READ (ver READ ), instrucción REWRITE (ver REWRITE ) y declaración WRITE (ver WRITE ). Incluso con DB_HOME, el bloqueo no funcionará con ORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL (ver ORGANIZATION SEQUENTIAL ), ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL (ver ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL ) o archivos ORGANIZATION RELATIVOS con compilaciones GnuCOBOL creadas para Windows / MinGW. trans-unit.source: If, on the other hand, the compiler

If, on the other hand, the compiler "config" file you used to compile the program specified "mf" as the "assign-clause" value, then the File Locator String will be interpreted according to according to IBM COBOL rules — namely, the File Locator String is expected to be of the form "S-xxx" or "AS-xxx", in which case the "xxx" will be treated as the base of an environment variable name. If there is no "-" character in the File Locator String then the entire File Locator String will serve as the base of an environment variable name.
trans-unit.target: Si, por otro lado, el archivo "config" del compilador que usó para compilar el programa especificó "mf" como el valor de la "cláusula de asignación", entonces la cadena del localizador de archivos se interpretará de acuerdo con las reglas de IBM COBOL, es decir, Se espera que la cadena del localizador de archivos tenga el formato "S-xxx" o "AS-xxx", en cuyo caso "xxx" se tratará como la base de un nombre de variable de entorno. Si no hay un carácter "-" en la cadena del localizador de archivos, toda la cadena del localizador de archivos servirá como base de un nombre de variable de entorno.

In the above examples, a comma is used as a separator character between the two subscript values; semicolons (;) are also valid subscript separator characters, as are spaces! The use of a comma or semicolon separator in such a situation is technically optional, but by convention most COBOL programmers use one or the other. The use of no separator character (other than a space) is not recommended, even though it is syntactically correct, as this practice can lead to programmer-unfriendly code. It isn’t too difficult to read and understand GRID-CHARACTER(2 3), but it’s another story entirely when trying to comprehend GRID-CHARACTER(I + 1 J / 3) (instead of GRID-CHARACTER(I + 1, J / 3)). The compiler accepts it, but too much of this would make

trans-unit.source: Including an ON SIZE ERROR clause on an arithmetic statement will allow your program to trap a failure of an arithmetic statement (either generating a result too large for the receiving field, or attempting to divide by zero) and handle it gracefully by executing imperative-statement-1 (see Imperative Statement). Field size overflow conditions occur silently, usually without any runtime messages being generated, even though such events rarely lend themselves to generating correct results. Division by zero errors, when no ON SIZE ERROR clause exists, will produce an error message (by the GnuCOBOL runtime library) to the SYSERR device (pipe 2) and will also abort the program.

Including anON SIZE ERRORclause on an arithmetic statement will allow your program to trap a failure of an arithmetic statement (either generating a result too large for the receiving field, or attempting to divide by zero) and handle it gracefully by executing <

trans-unit.source: Indexed files, like relative files, may have their records processed in either a sequential or random manner. Unlike relative files, however, the actual location of a record in an indexed file is calculated automatically based upon the value(s) of one or more alphanumeric fields within records of the file. For example, an indexed file containing product data might use the product identification code as a record key. This means you may read, write or update the A6G4328th record or the Z8X7723th record directly, based upon the product id value of those records!
Indexing is the process of referencing an element of a table utilizing a data item with an explicitly or implicitly defined USAGE (see USAGE) of INDEX to select the desired occurrence, while …

It would appear that it should be possible to locate and process any record in the file directly simply by calculating its starting character position based upon the program-defined record size. Even so, however, records must be still be read or written to these files in a purely sequential manner. The only way to read (or write) record number 100 would be to have read (or written) records number 1 through 99 first.
trans-unit.target: Parecería que debería ser posible localizar y procesar cualquier registro del archivo directamente,simplemente calculando la posición de su carácter inicial en función del tamaño del registro definido por el programa.Sin embargo,aún así,los registros deben ser leídos o escritos en estos archivos de una manera puramente secuencial.La única manera de leer (o escribir)el registro número 100 sería haber leído (o escrito)primero los registros del número 1 al 99.

trans-unit.source: It’s impossible to perform any arithmetic operation against an index data item directly (other than a simple incrementation or decremental operation via the SET UP/DOWN statement (see SET UP/DOWN)). Situations where any non-trivial computations are required to calculate the effective occurrence number for a table reference will require you to use a conventional unedited numeric data item as the receiving field for the calculation. That calculated value would then need to be saved into the index data item via a SET Index statement.

It’s impossible to perform any arithmetic operation against an index data item directly (other than a simple incrementation or decremental operation via theSET UP/DOWNstatement (see SET UP/DOWN)). Situations where any non-trivial computations are required to calculate the effective occurrence number for a table reference will require you to use a conventional unedited numeric data item as the receiving field for the calculation. That calculated value would then need to be saved into the index data item via aSET Indexstatement.
trans-unit.target: Es imposible realizar ninguna operación aritmética directamente contra un elemento de datos de índice (que no sea una simple operación de incremento o decremento a través de la instrucción SET UP/DOWN (ver SET UP / DOWN )). Las situaciones en las que se requieren cálculos no triviales para calcular el número de ocurrencia efectivo para una referencia de tabla requerirán que use un elemento de datos numérico convencional sin editar como campo de recepción para el cálculo. Ese valor calculado deberá guardarse en el elemento de datos de índice a través de una declaración de SET Index .

Legend has it that there’s actually only been ONE program ever written in COBOL, and all programs ever "written" thereafter were simply derivatives of that one. Although this is clearly intended as a (probably) bad joke, it is nevertheless close to the very simple truth that many programmers"reuse" existing COBOL programs when creating new ones. There’s certainly nothing preventing this from happening with programs written in other languages, but it does seem to happen more in COBOL shops. It’s ironic that "code re-usability" is one of the arguments used to justify the existence of the "modern" languages.
trans-unit.target: Cuenta la leyenda que en realidad solo se ha escrito UN programa en COBOL, y todos los programas que se "escribieron" a partir de entonces fueron simplemente derivados de ese. Aunque esto está claramente pensado como una (probablemente) broma de mal gusto, no obstante se acerca a la muy simple verdad de que muchos programadores "reutilizan" programas COBOL existentes al crear programas nuevos. Ciertamente, no hay nada que impida que esto suceda con programas escritos en otros idiomas, pero parece que sucede más en las tiendas COBOL. Es irónico que la "reutilización del código" sea uno de los argumentos que se utilizan para justificar la existencia de los lenguajes "modernos".

trans-unit.source: Legend has it that there’s actually only been ONE program ever written in COBOL, and all programs ever “written” thereafter were simply derivatives of that one. Although this is clearly intended as a (probably) bad joke, it is nevertheless close to the very simple truth that many programmers“reuse” existing COBOL programs when creating new ones. There’s certainly nothing preventing this from happening with programs written in other languages, but it does seem to happen more in COBOL shops. It’s ironic that “code re-usability” is one of the arguments used to justify the existence of the “modern” languages.

Let’s look at a different problem. Surely a program that asks a user to input a positive integer, generates the sum of all positive integers from 1 to that number and then prints the result will be MUCH shorter and MUCH easier to understand when coded in Java than in COBOL, right?
trans-unit.target: Veamos un problema diferente. Seguramente un programa que le pide a un usuario que ingrese un entero positivo, genera la suma de todos los enteros positivos desde 1 hasta ese número y luego imprime el resultado será MUCHO más corto y MUCHO más fácil de entender cuando se codifique en Java que en COBOL, ¿verdad?

trans-unit.source: Let’s look at how much more "wordy" COBOL is than Java. Count the characters in the two programs. The Java program has 95 (not counting carriage returns and any indentation). The COBOL program has 89 (again, not counting carriage returns and indentation)! Technically, it could have been only 65 because theIDENTIFICATION DIVISION.header is actually optional. Clearly, "Hello World" doesn’t look any more concise in Java than it does in COBOL.
trans-unit.target: Veamos cuánto más "prolijo" es COBOL que Java. Cuenta los personajes en los dos programas. El programa Java tiene 95 (sin contar los retornos de carro y cualquier sangría). El programa COBOL tiene 89 (de nuevo, sin contar los retornos de carro y la sangría). Técnicamente, podría haber sido solo 65 porque la IDENTIFICATION DIVISION. El encabezado es realmente opcional. Claramente, "Hello World" no parece más conciso en Java que en COBOL.

trans-unit.source: Let’s look at how much more “wordy” COBOL is than Java. Count the characters in the two programs. The Java program has 95 (not counting carriage returns and any indentation). The COBOL program has 89 (again, not counting carriage returns and indentation)! Technically, it could have been only 65 because the IDENTIFICATION DIVISION. header is actually optional. Clearly, “Hello World” doesn’t look any more concise in Java than it does in COBOL.

trans-unit.source: Level numbers in the range 1 through 49 indicate the position of a data item in the hierarchical structure of a logical record. Level numbers in the range 1 through 9 can be written either as a single digit or as a zero followed by the significant digit.

trans-unit.source: Like line sequential files, these files should not be defined to contain any exact binary data fields because the contents of those fields could inadvertently have the end-of-record sequence as part of their values — this would confuse the runtime system when reading the file, and it would interpret that value as an actual end-of-record sequence.
trans-unit.target: Al igual que los archivos secuenciales de línea, estos archivos no deben definirse para contener ningún campo de datos binarios exactos porque el contenido de esos campos podría tener inadvertidamente la secuencia de fin de registro como parte de sus valores; esto confundiría al sistema de tiempo de ejecución al leer el archivo. , e interpretaría ese valor como una secuencia real de fin de registro.

trans-unit.source: Like most other implementations of the COBOL language, GnuCOBOL utilizes a run-time library. When the first program executed in a given execution sequence is a GnuCOBOL program, any run-time library initialization will be performed by the compiled COBOL code in a manner that is transparent to the C-language programmer. If, however, a C program is the first to execute, the burden of performing GnuCOBOL run-time library initialization falls upon the C program. See C Main Programs Calling GnuCOBOL Subprograms, for an example of how to do this.
trans-unit.target: Como la mayoría de las otras implementaciones del lenguaje COBOL, GnuCOBOL utiliza una biblioteca en tiempo de ejecución. Cuando el primer programa ejecutado en una secuencia de ejecución dada es un programa GnuCOBOL, el código COBOL compilado realizará cualquier inicialización de la biblioteca en tiempo de ejecución de una manera que sea transparente para el programador en lenguaje C. Sin embargo, si un programa C es el primero en ejecutarse, la carga de realizar la inicialización de la biblioteca en tiempo de ejecución de GnuCOBOL recae sobre el programa C. Consulte C Programas principales que llaman a subprogramas GnuCOBOL , para ver un ejemplo de cómo hacer esto.

trans-unit.source: Literals are constant values that will not change during the execution of a program. There are two fundamental types of literals — numeric and alphanumeric.
Little-Endian
trans-unit.target: Little-Endian

trans-unit.source: Little-endian data allocation calls for the bytes that comprise a binary item to be allocated such that the least-significant byte is the left-most byte. For example, a four-byte binary item having a value of decimal 20 would be little-endian allocated as 14000000 (shown in hexadecimal notation).
trans-unit.target: La asignación de datos de poco tiempo exige que los bytes que componen un elemento binario se asignen de manera que el byte menos significativo sea el byte más a la izquierda.Por ejemplo,un elemento binario de cuatro bytes que tenga un valor de 20 decimal sería un "little-endian" asignado como 14000000 (que se muestra en notación hexadecimal).

trans-unit.source: Management of areas on the printed page such as top-of page headers, bottom-of-page footers, dealing with “full page” situations and the like are now the joint responsibility of the programmer and the GnuCOBOL run-time library, which provides tools such as the LINAGE-COUNTER special register (see Special Registers) and the END-OF-PAGE clause to deal with page formatting issues.

Many COBOL compilers do not allow the use of VALUE and OCCURS (see OCCURS) on the same data item; additionally, they don’t allow a VALUE clause on a data item subordinate to an OCCURS. GnuCOBOL, however, has neither of these restrictions!

Many COBOL compilers do not allow the use ofVALUEandOCCURS(see OCCURS) on the same data item; additionally, they don’t allow aVALUEclause on a data item subordinate to anOCCURS GnuCOBOL, however, has neither of these restrictions!
trans-unit.target: Muchos compiladores de COBOL no permiten el uso de VALUE y OCCURS (consulte OCCURS ) en el mismo elemento de datos; Además, no permiten una VALUE cláusula sobre un subordinado elemento de datos a un OCCURS GnuCOBOL, sin embargo, tiene ninguna de estas restricciones!

Many times these businesses are finding the cost of the system/networking engineering, operational management and monitoring and risk management (i.e. disaster recovery) infrastructures necessary to support truly mission-critical applications to be so high that the "less-expensive" solution really isn’t; in these cases the mainframe may remain the best option, thus leaving COBOL in play and businesses seeking another solution for at least part of their application base.
trans-unit.target: Muchas veces, estas empresas encuentran que el costo de las infraestructuras de ingeniería de sistemas / redes, administración operativa y monitoreo y administración de riesgos (es decir, recuperación de desastres) necesarias para respaldar aplicaciones verdaderamente de misión crítica es tan alto que la solución "menos costosa" realmente no lo es. 't; en estos casos, el mainframe puede seguir siendo la mejor opción, dejando a COBOL en juego y las empresas que buscan otra solución para al menos una parte de su base de aplicaciones.

Marking changes becomes more of a challenge when free-format source code is in effect. Creating a top-of-program comment block to generically describe changes that have been made isn’t difficult, even in free-form. What

Marking changes becomes more of a challenge when free-format source code is in effect. Creating a top-of-program comment block to generically describe changes that have been made isn’t difficult, even in free-form. What IS difficult, however, is coming up with a scheme for per-statement mark up of changes that doesn’t introduce a ridiculously excessive number of source lines to the program. I’m not sure there is a good answer to this problem (if a reader has one, please let me know). Generally, I’ve noticed that shops using free-format conventions for their COBOL source tend to stick with just the top-of-program comment block combined with minimal comment blocks sprinkled throughout the program noting areas that underwent major changes.
trans-unit.target: Marcar los cambios se convierte en un desafío mayor cuando el código fuente de formato libre está en vigor. La creación de un bloque de comentarios en la parte superior del programa para describir genéricamente los cambios que se han realizado no es difícil, incluso en forma libre. Lo que ES difícil, sin embargo, es idear un esquema para el marcado de cambios por declaración que no introduzca un número ridículamente excesivo de líneas fuente en el programa. No estoy seguro de que haya una buena respuesta a este problema (si un lector tiene una, hágamelo saber). En general, he notado que las tiendas que usan convenciones de formato libre para su fuente COBOL tienden a quedarse solo con el bloque de comentarios de la parte superior del programa combinado con bloques de comentarios mínimos esparcidos por todo el programa, señalando las áreas que sufrieron cambios importantes.

trans-unit.source: Most other COBOL implementations reject the use of multiple occurrences of multiple floating editing symbols. For example, they would reject <
trans-unit.target: La mayoría de las otras implementaciones de COBOL rechazan el uso de múltiples apariciones de múltiples símbolos de edición flotantes. Por ejemplo, rechazarían <

trans-unit.source: Most other COBOL implementations reject the use of multiple occurrences of multiple floating editing symbols. For example, they would reject picture-strings such as +++$$$9.99, $$$ZZZ9.99 and so on. GnuCOBOL accepts these. Programmers creating GnuCOBOL programs should avoid such picture-strings if there is any likelihood that those programs may be used with other COBOL implementations.

trans-unit.source: Multiple space-delimited tokens may be treated as a single token by enclosing them in quotes. For example, there are only three tokens generated from the command line C:\Pgms\myprog.exe "THIS IS A" TEST — "C:\Pgms\myprog.exe", "THIS IS A" and "TEST". When quote characters are used to create multi-word tokens, the quote characters themselves are stripped from the token’s value.
trans-unit.target: Se pueden tratar varios tokens delimitados por espacios como un solo token encerrándolos entre comillas. Por ejemplo, solo hay tres tokens generados desde la línea de comando C:\Pgms\myprog.exe "THIS IS A" TEST - "C: \ Pgms \ myprog.exe", "ESTO ES A" y "PRUEBA". Cuando se utilizan caracteres de comillas para crear tokens de varias palabras, los mismos caracteres de comillas se eliminan del valor del token.

trans-unit.source: Multiple space-delimited tokens may be treated as a single token by enclosing them in quotes. For example, there are only three tokens generated from the command line C:\Pgms\myprog.exe ‘THIS IS A’ TEST — ‘
